content.question: A quantity of <math alttext="10,000 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></math> of thermal energy is transferred to four different substances. In which of the following experiments could the greatest mass of the given substance undergo the indicated change?

choices.label: Melting ice at <math alttext="0, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> to form liquid water at <math alttext="0, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, delta H sub fusion, end sub, equals 300 joules per gram, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>330</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

Boiling liquid acetone at <math alttext="56 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>56</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> to form acetone vapor at <math alttext="56 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>56</mn><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, delta H sub vaporization, equals 540 joules per gram, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>540</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

Increasing the temperature of liquid glycerin from <math alttext="20, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> to <math alttext="120, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>120</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, Specific heat equals 2.4 joules per gram degrees Celsius, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>Specific</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>heat</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.4</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo>/</mo><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>·</mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

Increasing the temperature of solid copper from <math alttext="0, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> to <math alttext="200, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>200</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, Specific heat equals 0.40 joule per gram degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>Specific</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>heat</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo>/</mo><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>·</mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

content.answer: Increasing the temperature of solid copper from <math alttext="0, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> to <math alttext="200, decimal point, degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>200</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> <math alttext="open parenthesis, Specific heat equals 0.40 joule per gram degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>Specific</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>heat</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo>/</mo><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>·</mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
